issue.title: Conda-build generates package with no functions
issue.body:
### Actual Behavior

Hi guys,

I've been trying to build a very simple conda package from the file TestFunctions.py.
```
| Temp/
	| - src/
        	| - TestFunctions.py
	| - meta.yaml
	| - bld.bat
	| - setup.py
```

However, conda-build generates a testpackage-0.0.1-0.tar.bz2 but with no functions.
(the tarball does not have the lib folder, just the info folder)

I've also tried some changes such as:
- using build.script and pip rather than setuptools
- using (1) build, host and run, (2) build and run and (3) host and run
- remove and recreate the conda env
- reinstall conda

But had no luck. 

From the docs and examples I've seen, it should have worked but it seems it's not creating the "temporary" conda environments (_build_env?) as expected.

### Expected Behavior

Conda-build should have generated a testpackage-0.0.1-py37-0.tar.bz2 with two functions: TestA and TestB.

### Steps to Reproduce

conda create --name Temp-dev-env --no-default-package python=3.7 conda-build m2-patch
conda activate Temp-dev-env

conda build .

##### src/TestFunctions.py

```
def TestA(x, y):
   return x + y

def TestB(x ,y):
   return x * y
```

##### meta.yaml

```
package: 
    name: "testpackage"
    version: "0.0.1"

source:
    path: .

build:
    # script: "python -m pip install . --no-deps --ignore-installed -vv"

requeriments:
    build:
        # - pip
        - setuptools
    host:
        - python
    run:
        - python
```
  
##### setup.py

from setuptools import setup, find_packages

```
setup(
    name="testpackage",
    version="0.0.1",
    packages=find_packages(include=["src", "src.*"]),
)
```

##### bld.bat

```
python setup.py install
if errorlevel 1 exit 1
```

issue.title: KeyError: 0
issue.body:
### Actual Behavior

`conda index <channel-path>` fails with an exception:
```console
$ ~/conda/bin/conda index stable
Subdir: noarch: 100%|████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████████| 2/2 [00:03<00:00,  2.00s/it]
Traceback (most recent call last):: 0it [00:00, ?it/s].bz2: 100%|██████████████████| 12/12 [00:01<00:00,  6.70it/s]
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda_build/index.py", line 346, in _clear_newline_chars
    record[field_name] = record[field_name].strip().replace('\n', ' ')
AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'strip'

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/user/conda/bin/conda-index", line 11, in <module>
    sys.exit(main())
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda_build/cli/main_index.py", line 75, in main
    return execute(sys.argv[1:])
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda_build/cli/main_index.py", line 71, in execute
    verbose=args.verbose, progress=args.progress, hotfix_source_repo=args.hotfix_source_repo)
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda_build/api.py", line 390, in update_index
    hotfix_source_repo=hotfix_source_repo)
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda_build/index.py", line 273, in update_index
    patch_generator=patch_generator, verbose=verbose, progress=progress, hotfix_source_repo=hotfix_source_repo)
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda_build/index.py", line 844, in index
    channel_data, package_mtimes = self._build_channeldata(subdirs, reference_packages)
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda_build/index.py", line 1188, in _build_channeldata
    data = future.result()
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/concurrent/futures/_base.py", line 432, in result
    return self.__get_result()
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/concurrent/futures/_base.py", line 384, in __get_result
    raise self._exception
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/concurrent/futures/thread.py", line 56, in run
    result = self.fn(*self.args, **self.kwargs)
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda_build/index.py", line 1104, in _load_all_from_cache
    _clear_newline_chars(data, 'summary')
  File "/home/user/conda/lib/python3.6/site-packages/conda_build/index.py", line 349, in _clear_newline_chars
    record[field_name] = record[field_name][0].strip().replace('\n', ' ')
KeyError: 0
```

### Expected Behavior
 
`conda index <channel-path>` indexes the channel

### Steps to Reproduce

It does not fail deterministically, but when it fails once, it will continue to fail for that channel.

comment.body:
This can also happen if you have a colon in your package description in your setup.py and use jinja templates to copy the description into your recipe:

```python
# setup.py
setup(...
   description='Warning: this will break conda build!'
)
```

```yaml
# meta.yaml
...
about:
  summary: {{ data['description'] }}
```

Even worse, this stays in the build cache and prevents further builds from working
even if you fix the summary string. I had to grovel the `conda-bld/.cache` directory
and manually clean up the broken package.

issue.title: py37 selector is not supported
issue.body:
conda-build supports selectors for `py27` through `py36` but not `py37`.  This leads to unexpected results if this selector is used:

```
$ cat meta.yaml 
package:
  name: foobar
  version: 1.0.0

requirements:
  host:
    - python
    - example1  # [py37]
    - example2  # [not py37]
$ cat conda_build_config.yaml 
python:
  - 3.6
  - 3.7
$ conda render .
Returning non-final recipe for foobar-1.0.0-0; one or more dependencies was unsatisfiable:
Host: example2
--------------
Hash contents:
--------------
{}
----------
meta.yaml:
----------
package:
    name: foobar
    version: 1.0.0
requirements:
    host:
        - python 3.6.*
        - example2
extra:
    copy_test_source_files: true
    final: true

--------------
Hash contents:
--------------
{}
----------
meta.yaml:
----------
package:
    name: foobar
    version: 1.0.0
requirements:
    host:
        - python 3.7.*
        - example2
extra:
    copy_test_source_files: true
    final: true
```

Compare this to using comparison selectors:

```
$ cat meta.yaml 
package:
  name: foobar
  version: 1.0.0

requirements:
  host:
    - python
    - example1  # [py==37]
    - example2  # [not py==37]
$ conda render .
Returning non-final recipe for foobar-1.0.0-0; one or more dependencies was unsatisfiable:
Host: example1
Host: example2
--------------
Hash contents:
--------------
{}
----------
meta.yaml:
----------
package:
    name: foobar
    version: 1.0.0
requirements:
    host:
        - example1
        - python 3.7.*
extra:
    copy_test_source_files: true
    final: true

--------------
Hash contents:
--------------
{}
----------
meta.yaml:
----------
package:
    name: foobar
    version: 1.0.0
requirements:
    host:
        - example2
        - python 3.6.*
extra:
    copy_test_source_files: true
    final: true
```

comment.body:
It would be great if the CI for feedstocks that use non-existing version selectors (like `py37`) would fail.

We've been using `py37` for some time (`skip: True  # [not (py27 or py34 or py35 or py36 or py37)]`), not noticing that it does not work, and not being notified about the fact that it does not exist.

issue.title: Unable to force the Visual Studio 2017 compiler for a python 2.7.15 build of yt
issue.body:
Following an initial problem solved at #3872, I have built yt against python 2.7.15 using `conda build --python 2.7.15 yt` followed by `conda install --use-local yt`.

However, I realised that `conda build` compiled yt's python 2.7.15 using Visual Studio 2008, when I need it to be compiled with Visual Studio 2017 (to be compatible with the python 2.7.15 running in Houdini, into which I want to import yt).

I therefore followed the instructions here:
```
https://docs.conda.io/projects/conda-build/en/latest/resources/compiler-tools.html#using-your-customized-compiler-package-with-conda-build-3
```

I edited the `conda_build_config.yaml` inside `C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\pkgs\yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0\info\recipe` to replace `c_compiler: vs2008 ` with `c_compiler: vs2017` and `cxx_compiler: vs2008 ` with `cxx_compiler: vs2017` and `vc: '9'` with `vc: '14.16'`.

However, when I then ran `conda build --python 2.7.15 yt`, I noticed the following messages during the build:
```
%SRC_DIR%>set "vc=9"
%SRC_DIR%>set "cxx_compiler=vs2008"
%SRC_DIR%>echo "Found VS2008 at"
"Found VS2008 at"
%SRC_DIR%>echo "C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 9.0\Common7\IDE\"
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 9.0\Common7\IDE\"
%SRC_DIR%>SET "VS_VERSION=9.0"
%SRC_DIR%>SET "VS_MAJOR=9"
%SRC_DIR%>SET "VS_YEAR=2008"

```
So, the build was using `Visual Studio 2008` rather than the `Visual Studio 2017` that I specified in the `conda_build_config.yaml` edits.

I'm obviously doing something wrong but I don't know what!  

During the build, I've noticed that the entire `yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0` directory in `C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\pkgs` disappears and then is overwritten with a fresh version.  Inside that, the `conda_build_config.yaml` in `C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\pkgs\yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0\info\recipe` has reverted back to its original Visual Studio 2008 settings.

I don't know how to stop that happening.  

I'm not even sure how `yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0` gets into `C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\pkgs` in the first place.  I've tried deleting it prior to restarting my sequence of commands leading up to `conda build` again and have noticed that it reappears when I install prerequisite dependencies:
```
conda install -c conda-forge cython git sympy ipython numpy matplotlib netCDF4
```
For some reason, yt is also getting installed with these, even though it's not specified.  I don't know why.  It might be because of something I've done way back and now forgotten...

The overwriting of `yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0` with a fresh version seems to be wiping out the `conda_build_config.yaml` edits, preventing the compiler being changed from Visual Studio 2008 to Visual Studio 2017.

Alternatively, could the reversion to Visual Studio 2008 be because I'm editing the wrong `conda_build_config.yaml` file?  But I can't find another one - for example, there's no yt package in my env's `.../Lib/site-packages.`  Or maybe I need to do an edit to my env's `meta.yaml` file as well as to the `conda_build_config.yaml`?

I'd appreciate your suggestions.

comment.body:
OK, many thanks for that advice - another big learning step for me!  I'll look into the pip approach.  Windows seems to be quite a problem with Houdini - building OpenVDB for it was a real effort, although I got there in the end.

Another option I have is to dual boot and do it all with Linux, which seems to be more straight forward.

I've got some thinking and more learning to do!

Thanks again.

I edited the `conda_build_config.yaml` inside `C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\pkgs\yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0\info\recipe` to replace `c_compiler: vs2008 ` with `c_compiler: vs2017` and `cxx_compiler: vs2008 ` with `cxx_compiler: vs2017` and `vc: '9'` with `vc: '14.16'`.

However, when I then ran `conda build --python 2.7.15 yt`, I noticed the following messages during the build:
```
%SRC_DIR%>set "vc=9"
%SRC_DIR%>set "cxx_compiler=vs2008"

Inside that, the `conda_build_config.yaml` in `C:\ProgramData\Miniconda2\pkgs\yt-3.5.1-py27hc997a72_0\info\recipe` has reverted back to its original Visual Studio 2008 settings.

But I can't find another one - for example, there's no yt package in my env's `.../Lib/site-packages.`  Or maybe I need to do an edit to my env's `meta.yaml` file as well as to the `conda_build_config.yaml`?

I'd appreciate your suggestions.

comment.body:
Each installation of Python is built slightly differently, but actually, the Houdini one is built very differently, electing to use a different newer C-Runtime than is standard for Python 2.7.

These C-Runtimes are incompatible. Objects cannot be passed between them safely because their layouts and sizes differ.

For that reason, you should not load both into the same process.

But, that's just another gotcha here specific to Windows.

The Python software building ecosystem (such that that is something we could define) uses the running python executable for two reasons, both to drive the build (and compilation of any C/C++) and as the final install location for packages (the site-packages dir).

Mixing two very different Pythons here is not something you should do. The houdini Python should be the interpreter in charge of building the software that it will eventually run. This applies to any 3rd party interpreters.

The only way I see to reasonably use `conda-build` to _help_ you (as opposed to introduce a whole set of different problems) - though I also question if this is necessary in the first place, why not just pip install yt from source from the houdini Python interpreter? - would be if you were to make a special `houdini-python` package and use that in your host env during the build.

I therefore installed `vs2017_runtime` to my env using `conda install -c peterjc123 vs2017_runtime` in accordance with [https://anaconda.org/peterjc123/vs2017_runtime](url), and reran conda-build but conda-build still used `vs2015_runtime` and I got the same errors. I thought about using the `.condarc` file to somehow force conda-build to use `vs2017_runtime` but I couldn't find any command to do this with. So, I'm at a loss as to how to overcome my errors. FYI, here are my `meta.yaml` and `conda_build_config.yaml` files.

meta.yaml ``` {% set version = "3.5.1" %} {% set sha256 = "c8ef8eceb934dc189d63dc336109fad3002140a9a32b19f38d1812d5d5a30d71" %} package: name: yt version: {{ version }} source: fn: yt-{{ version }}.tar.gz url: http://yt-project.org/sdist/yt-{{ version }}.tar.gz sha256: {{ sha256 }} build: number: 0 script: python setup.py -q install --single-version-externally-managed --record=record.txt entry_points: - yt = yt.utilities.command_line:run_main requirements: build: - {{ compiler('c') }} - {{ compiler('cxx') }} host: - python - numpy - cython >=0.24.0 - setuptools >=19.6 run: - setuptools - python - {{ pin_compatible('numpy') }} - h5py - sympy - matplotlib - ipython test: requires: - nose commands: - yt -h imports: - yt about: home: http://yt-project.org/ license: BSD 3-clause summary: Analysis and visualization toolkit for volumetric data extra: recipe-maintainers: - ngoldbaum - munkm ```

conda_build_config.yaml ``` c_compiler: vs2017 cpu_optimization_target: nocona cran_mirror: https://cran.r-project.org cxx_compiler: vs2017 extend_keys: - ignore_build_only_deps - extend_keys - ignore_version - pin_run_as_build fortran_compiler: gfortran ignore_build_only_deps: - python- numpy lua: '5' numpy: '1.11' perl: 5.26.0 pin_run_as_build: python: max_pin: x.x min_pin: x.x r-base: max_pin: x.x min_pin: x.x python: 2.7.15 r_base: '3.4' target_platform: win-64 vc: '14.16' #matches MSVC++ 14.16 _MSC_VER == 1916 (Visual Studio 2017 version 15.9) #Also tried 15.4 to match vs2017_runtime-15.4.27004.2010-1 ```

I'd be grateful for further help!

issue.title: Intermittent ChecksumMismatchError for locally built package
issue.body:
<!--
Thanks for opening an issue! A few things to keep in mind:

- This issue tracker is for issues with or enhancements for conda-build.

Anaconda Community Code of Conduct: https://www.anaconda.com/community-code-of-conduct/

For conda issues, you should open an issue at https://github.com/conda/conda/issues
For Anaconda issues, you should open an issue at https://github.com/ContinuumIO/anaconda-issues/issues
For an issue with a particular conda-forge package, you should open an issue on the 
corresponding feedstock: https://github.com/conda-forge
-->

### Actual Behavior

We build a conda package and distribute it internally on our own conda channel. We use Jenkins CI to create a new build and update the channel for each commit. 

Every so often, a user tries to `conda install` the package and it fails with a ChecksumMismatchError.

```
ChecksumMismatchError: Conda detected a mismatch between the expected content and downloaded content
for url 'http://channelserver:85/prod/win-64/jbagdal-2.2.0-py36_vc14h830ac7b_0.tar.bz2'.
  download saved to: C:\bin\Miniconda3\pkgs\jbagdal-2.2.0-py36_vc14h830ac7b_0.tar.bz2
  expected sha256: 82240e245a1a3e2931f2c2a80a4a6f729d18da544d127f96591706bcdd70b182
  actual sha256: 2a7a320f8e606224dfd4bba03d81c6e6b817ce3f95089d418103ca17d310fa73
```

### Expected Behavior

`conda install` should install the package without error.

### Steps to Reproduce

It's a tricky one to reproduce, because sometimes the checksums are ok and sometimes they are not. We've tried reindexing the channel, with
```
conda index \\path\to\conda\channel -c
```
and this sometimes fixes the problem and sometimes does not. I ran it this morning and it seems that `index.html` in the `win-64` subdirectory was not updated. Maybe this is the problem?

```
09/12/2019  18:32    <DIR>          .
09/12/2019  18:32    <DIR>          ..
09/12/2019  18:32           101,235 repodata2.json
13/01/2020  14:57            41,908 index.html
29/01/2020  09:19            89,568 repodata.json
29/01/2020  09:19            10,674 repodata.json.bz2
             119 File(s)    649,870,617 bytes
               3 Dir(s)  498,415,505,408 bytes free
```

Eventually, the problem does go away, I think when Jenkins does another build and updates the channel. So, sorry I can't give a better repro case, but as far as I can tell the problem is that sometimes `conda build` and/or `conda index` do not update the expected checksums properly.

##### `Output of conda info`
<!-- Between the ticks below, paste the output of 'conda info' -->
```
     active environment : c:\jenkins2\env\Farmmap_conda_windows
    active env location : c:\jenkins2\env\Farmmap_conda_windows
            shell level : 1
       user config file : C:\Users\jontwo\.condarc
 populated config files : C:\bin\Miniconda3\.condarc
                          C:\Users\jontwo\.condarc
                          c:\jenkins2\env\Farmmap_conda_windows\.condarc
          conda version : 4.7.12
    conda-build version : not installed
         python version : 3.7.3.final.0
       virtual packages :
       base environment : C:\bin\Miniconda3  (writable)
           channel URLs : http://channelserver:85/prod/win-64
                          http://channelserver:85/prod/noarch
                          http://channelserver:85/dev/win-64
                          http://channelserver:85/dev/noarch
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/win-64
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/main/noarch
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/win-64
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/r/noarch
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/msys2/win-64
                          https://repo.anaconda.com/pkgs/msys2/noarch
                          https://conda.anaconda.org/conda-forge/win-64
                          https://conda.anaconda.org/conda-forge/noarch
          package cache : C:\bin\Miniconda3\pkgs
                          C:\Users\jontwo\.conda\pkgs
                          C:\Users\jontwo\AppData\Local\conda\conda\pkgs
       envs directories : C:\bin\Miniconda3\envs
                          C:\Users\jontwo\.conda\envs
                          C:\Users\jontwo\AppData\Local\conda\conda\envs
               platform : win-64
             user-agent : conda/4.7.12 requests/2.22.0 CPython/3.7.3 Windows/201
2ServerR2 Windows/6.3.9600
          administrator : False
             netrc file : None
           offline mode : False

```
Not sure why it says conda-build is not installed (this is info for base conda?), because `conda list` says
```
conda                     4.6.14                   py37_0    conda-forge
conda-build               3.17.8                   py37_1    conda-forge
conda-verify              3.1.1                 py37_1000    conda-forge
```

comment.body: That makes sense. You would have thought running another build would cause the problem, not fix it.
